post.title: Sewing with EMG electrodes!
post.author: Mollie Myers
post.content: In order to help facilitate consistent placement of the electrodes for the eventual user of our device, and also to help with keeping the electrodes fixed to the skin without using extremely harsh adhesives, we have been working on a type of sleeve that would have the wires sewn into small-wire shaped pockets with holes cut at the wire heads in order to allow the electrodes to still be snapped on. We have tried this on both blood-pressure cuff (which, in extra large size could be wrapped around the leg) and with compression shorts like these .

post.title: First Motor
post.author: Joshua Friscia
post.content: Recently our first motor arrived in the mail. We'll be using Firgelli P16 linear actuators to control the hydraulic action of our syringes. The actuator has a Max lift Force of 50N, a backdrive force of 75N, and a stroke length of 150mm. These specs provide us with enough force inflate the bladders, counteracting the force the user's limb applies to the bladders and ensuring the motor won't get backdriven. More to come on testing the actuator and hydraulic system.

post.title: Gathering EMG Signal Data
post.author: Mollie Myers
post.content: On November 13, we went to the Rec Center to gather some EMG data. This data is being used to further develop our algorithm to determine the user state. For the first test, subject 1 (Meagan) walked approximately 8 yards, then stopped, and turned around. She repeated this several times. During this we were measuring activity on the rectus femoris muscle which was found from using this diagram as well as palpation. She also did the same thing but running. The final test with that muscle group was standing up from a sitting position and sitting down from a standing position. We performed the same tests with adductor magnus and the biceps femoris. We used a Bitalino to collect the data. So far we are very excited it seems like we can pretty confidently determine the difference in user activity, but more information is coming soon!

post.title: PUL Bladder Testing
post.author: Joshua Friscia
post.content: In our final attempt at prototyping bladders, we used Polyurethane Laminate (PUL) sealed with flowable sealant. The PUL is a realtively stretchy material compared to vinyl and when we pressurized it, the PUL began to slowly leak around the seams. As a result, we were unable to collect max pressure data from the PUL bladders. One takeaways from testing the PUL were that flowable sealant forms a more watertight bond, provided that it has several days to dry. The PUL is also a more comfortable fabric compared to vinyl, and might be useful in creating the lining or attachment for the vinyl bladders to the socket. The PUL could be turned into a liner with several pocket to house the vinly bladders in. This would also provide some extra protection from leaks if the vinyl bladders fail.

post.title: Weekly Update
post.author: Meagan Hiatt
post.content: This week we are finishing up the PCB (Printed Circuit Board) design and are planning to submit an order this Monday. Altium Designer is being used to design the board. All of the components, such as the microcontroller, motor drivers and EMG filtering circuits have been designed and their parts ordered.

post.title: Welcome
post.author: Jacob Zizmor
post.content: Hello! We are the Dynamic Adjustable Prosthetic Socket team from Worcester Polytechnic Institute. We are developing a lower-limb prosthetic socket to reduce strain on the wearer's residual limb and reduce excess energy put forth by the wearer. You can find a more detailed description on the projects page. So far, we have completed 7 weeks of our project. These first 7 weeks were spent researching, designing, and prototyping. One topic of the first 7 weeks of our work has been about EMG sensors. We have researched and tested locations to place EMG sensors to aquire the most accurate and representative signals. Additionally, we have worked to create appropriate electrical filters for the EMG signals to reduce noise and ease analysis. We will also be using a custom designed PCB board for our project. We've been designing our own schematic to use and we'll be placing our order soon. Our project is based on hydraulics. We've designed our hydraulic system and will begin testing soon. Part of the hydraulic system will be hydraulic bladders, which we will also be designing ourselves. So far, we've prototyped several different iterations of bladders focusing on different materials, sealing methods, and shapes. In order to control the entire system, we will be using an embedded microcontroller. The software has been outlined and being written now.
